div.p: C1.2: Materiality Assessment

A double materiality assessment informs strategic positioning by identifying impacts, risks, and opportunities. The process applies defined thresholds for impact and financial materiality, integrates stakeholder perspectives, and is reviewed [specify review frequency] under the oversight of [specify governance body responsible].

Building on this approach, the undertaking follows a structured methodology to determine which sustainability matters are significant for both the organization and its stakeholders. The assessment applies the principles of double materiality, examining each issue from two complementary perspectives:

ul.li: Impact materiality, evaluating the undertaking's actual and potential effects on the environment, society, and human rights;
Financial materiality, assessing how sustainability matters could influence financial performance, enterprise value, and strategic objectives.

div.p: The process incorporates insights from internal stakeholders (management, operations, procurement, ESG teams) and external stakeholders (suppliers, customers, communities, regulators), gathered through [specify methods used: workshops, interviews, surveys]. Issues are evaluated based on criteria such as scale, scope, remediability, likelihood, financial magnitude, and strategic relevance.
A consistent scoring model supports prioritization.

ul.li: Impact materiality is determined by scoring the scale, scope, and remediability of impacts (1-5), with an average score â‰¥ 3 considered material.
Financial materiality combines magnitude and likelihood (1-5) into a composite score, where â‰¥ 3 indicates financial significance.
A topic is considered double material when both impact and financial scores meet or exceed this threshold.

div.p: The assessment is governed by the ESG/DMA team, in coordination with the enterprise risk management function. Results are validated by executive leadership and relevant board committees, ensuring alignment with strategic priorities. Material issues identified feed directly into strategic planning, investment decisions, and operational improvements.

The assessment is updated [specify review frequency], or sooner if significant operational or regulatory changes occur. Continuous stakeholder feedback supports refinement of the methodology, including updates to scoring, thresholds, and evaluation criteria as the risk landscape evolves.

div.h1: B3: Energy Consumption and Greenhouse Gas Emissions
div.p: This section presents the undertaking's energy consumption and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in line with the VSME Standard (B3-29 to B3-31). The environmental topics included in this section reflect the undertaking's understanding of the most relevant environmental impacts associated with its activities, including [specify key environmental issues identified as relevant].

The undertaking operates in [describe type of facilities and their locations], consisting of [specify owned/leased sites] and managed by [specify facility management approach]. Due to the nature of its activities; [describe activity type, e.g., consulting, services, manufacturing], certain environmental impacts such as [non-relevant topics, if applicable] were not identified as significant.

The company monitors its energy consumption and associated GHG emissions using calculation tools integrated into its Odoo system, which are based on the GHG Protocol Corporate Standard. Emission data are updated on an ongoing basis as new accounting entries and activity data are recorded. Scope 1, Scope 2 and significant Scope 3 categories are calculated following recognised emission factors and methodological guidance.

Scope 3 categories such as employee commuting are estimated using employee-reported home-to-work distances, commuting modes, vehicle characteristics where applicable, and the organisation's homeworking policy to account only for days worked on site. Additional indirect emissions not directly linked to accounting daa, such as refrigerant gases, employee meals, or waste management, may be manually added using documented activity data and standard emission factors. When only estimates or partial information are available, the company applies reasonable assumptions consistent with VSME guidance.

div.p: C6.2: Human Rights Due-Diligence Process

div.p: C6.3: Incidents of Discrimination or Harassment

If incidents occur, appropriate corrective and disciplinary actions are implemented according to internal procedures.

div.p: B9: Workforce Health & Safety

div.h1: B9: Workforce Health & Safety
div.p: Workforce health and safety are fundamental priorities for {{ company_name }}. The organisation is committed to providing a safe, healthy and inclusive working environment for all employees. This commitment is based on a proactive approach that aims to prevent risks, promote responsible behaviours, and foster a workplace culture where physical and mental well-being are central.

Beyond regulatory compliance, {{ company_name }} promotes a culture of prevention, awareness and continuous improvement, recognising that protecting employee health and safety is essential both to individual fulfilment and the long-term performance of the organisation.

div.p: B9.4: Health & Safety Actions

{{ company_name }} implements actions to promote employee health, safety, and well-being across all workplaces, including on-site, remote, and business travel contexts. These initiatives focus on core occupational safety practices, such as ergonomic improvements, accident prevention, telework safety, mental health, and well-being programs.

The initiatives undertaken or planned are structured around primary focus areas, including risk prevention, workplace ergonomics, employee well-being, and awareness campaigns. These measures support continuous improvement in workplace safety and contribute to {{ company_name }}'s overall health and safety objectives.

record.field: B10: Workforce Remuneration, collective bargaining and training

div.p: B10: Workforce Remuneration, Collective Bargaining and Training

div.h1: B10: Workforce Remuneration, Collective Bargaining and Training
div.p: {{ company_name }} ensures fair and equitable remuneration for all employees, with compensation aligned with legal requirements, local labor standards, and applicable collective bargaining agreements. Remuneration practices include base salary, overtime, benefits, and additional fixed payments where relevant.

Collective bargaining agreements are respected where applicable, ensuring that employees' rights to negotiate terms of employment are recognized and maintained. Coverage includes all employees under agreements, not limited to union members, and reflects the company's commitment to transparent and fair labor relations.

Training and development are considered integral to employee growth, skill enhancement, and career progression. Employees have access to structured training programs, including mandatory onboarding, professional development, ESG or sustainability-related modules, and other targeted skill-building initiatives. Participation is tracked to ensure equal access across genders and roles.
These workforce initiatives support employee well-being, engagement, and retention, while fostering a culture of continuous learning and compliance with labor standards.
B10.1: Remuneration - Minimum Wage
This section discloses the percentage of employees whose compensation meets or exceeds the applicable minimum wage, based on local law or collective bargaining agreements.

Cross-check payroll and HR system data to ensure coverage across all locations and contract types.

div.h1: C7: Severe Negative Human Rights Incident
div.p: {{ company_name }} discloses any *confirmed severe negative human-rights incidents* that occurred during the reporting period.
According to EFRAG guidance, a â€œconfirmed incidentâ€ includes:

ul.li: a legal action or complaint formally registered with the company or authorities, or
a case of non-compliance identified through established procedures such as audits, monitoring systems, or grievance mechanisms.

div.p: This section focuses only on severe human-rights impacts related to the company's *own workforce*.
C7.1: Disclosure of Severe Human-Rights Incidents

record.field: B11: Convictions and Fines for Corruption and Bribery

div.p: B11: Convictions and Fines for Corruption and Bribery

div.h1: B11: Convictions and Fines for Corruption and Bribery
div.p: {{ company_name }} is committed to maintaining integrity, transparency, and ethical conduct in all business operations. Corruption and bribery are considered major business conduct sustainability issues, and the company reports on any convictions or fines related to anti-corruption and anti-bribery laws.
B11.1: Convictions for Corruption and Bribery

div.h2: B11.1: Convictions for Corruption and Bribery
div.p: Convictions refer to any verdict of a criminal court against an individual or the company for violating anti-corruption or anti-bribery laws. This includes convictions registered in the official criminal records of the relevant jurisdiction.

tr.td: Number of convictions for violating anti-corruption and anti-bribery laws

div.p: Track all legal cases, including ongoing investigations, and ensure proper classification. Even zero convictions should be reported to demonstrate proactive compliance.
B11.2: Fines for Corruption and Bribery

div.h2: B11.2: Fines for Corruption and Bribery
div.p: Fines refer to any mandatory monetary penalties imposed by a court, commission, or government authority for violations of anti-corruption and anti-bribery laws. These amounts are paid to public authorities.

B11.3: Internal Procedures and Controls

{{ company_name }} has implemented internal procedures and controls to prevent corruption, bribery, and unethical business conduct. These measures cover employee behavior, supplier management, financial approvals, and monitoring mechanisms to ensure compliance with anti-corruption laws and company policies.

div.p: Document all internal procedures clearly and update them regularly. Include training, monitoring, and reporting measures to demonstrate active governance. Track implementation status to show continuous improvement.

{{ company_name }} requires suppliers and partners to adhere to ethical standards, ensuring transparency, fairness, and compliance with anti-corruption rules.
